title: SOP for Handling and Ripening Bananas and Mangoes (Unripe vs. Ripe)

sections.title: Purpose
sections.content: To ensure consistent quality and safe handling of bananas and mangoes across the supply chain by controlling temperature, relative humidity (RH), ethylene exposure, ventilation/CO₂, and gentle handling for two conditions: unripe (green/near-mature) and ripe (ready-to-market).

sections.title: Definitions
sections.content:
Unripe: Firm, green/near-mature fruit suitable for transport and controlled ripening.
Ripe: Softer fruit ready for sale; more sensitive to bruising and temperature fluctuations.
Ripening chamber: A controlled room where ripening is accelerated using ethylene along with set temperature, RH, and ventilation to manage CO₂ and remove ethylene after treatment.

sections.title: Roles and Responsibilities
sections.content:
QC/Inspector: Incoming inspection, grading decisions (ripen/hold/reject), documentation.
Ripening Operator: Run ripening cycles (setpoints for temperature/RH/ethylene/ventilation) and monitor readings.
Warehouse/Logistics: Maintain cold chain, segregation rules, safe stacking/handling, FEFO dispatch for ripe fruit.

subsections.title: Incoming Receiving and Initial Sorting (Banana & Mango)
subsections.content:
1) Verify lot identity: supplier, lot/batch ID, arrival date/time, quantity, packaging condition.
2) Perform rapid visual QC (sampling): bruising, cuts, mold/rot, leakage (mango sap), crown damage (banana).
3) Categorize lot:
   - Unripe (eligible for controlled ripening/transport): not extremely immature and not overly mature.
   - Ripe/near-ripe: prioritize for quick dispatch; minimize re-handling.
4) Record findings with photos for HOLD/REJECT cases (optional but recommended).

subsections.title: Storage and Transport (Unripe vs. Ripe)
subsections.content:
General (especially for unripe):
- Pre-cool where feasible and keep temperature stable throughout transit.
- Avoid mixing commodities with incompatible temperature requirements.

Ethylene segregation (critical for unripe bananas and mangoes):
- Do not store/transport unripe bananas/mangoes together with strong ethylene-producing commodities (e.g., apples, avocados). Use separate zones/vehicles where possible.

Ripe fruit:
- Handle gently; limit stack height; reduce shocks; dispatch quickly using strict FIFO/FEFO.

subsections.title: Controlled Ripening in a Ripening Chamber
subsections.content:
Target RH during ripening: 90–95%.
Use commodity-specific setpoints and ensure ventilation/exhaust to manage CO₂ and remove ethylene after treatment.

subsections.title: Ripening Setpoints (Quick Reference)
subsections.content:
Banana:
- Ethylene: 100–150 ppm
- Exposure time: 24–48 hours
- Ripening temperature: 15–18°C
- Post-ripening storage temperature: 13–14°C

Mango:
- Ethylene: 100 ppm
- Exposure time: ~24 hours
- Ripening temperature: 20–22°C
- Post-ripening storage temperature: 10–13°C

subsections.title: Ventilation and CO₂ Control
subsections.content:
- Maintain CO₂ at a low level throughout ripening; as a practical guide, keep CO₂ below 5000 ppm.
- Use exhaust/ventilation to:
  (a) remove ethylene after the exposure period, and
  (b) prevent CO₂ build-up that can delay ripening or degrade quality.

subsections.title: Step-by-Step Ripening Cycle (Operator)
subsections.content:
1) Pre-check: cleanliness, door seals, sensor calibration (temperature/RH/CO₂).
2) Load fruit: allow airflow paths; avoid dead zones; do not over-stack.
3) Stabilize room: reach target temperature/RH before ethylene introduction.
4) Ethylene exposure: run for the specified duration.
5) Ventilate after exposure: purge ethylene and reduce CO₂.
6) Holding: keep fruit at the appropriate temperature until target ripeness is reached.
7) Record all readings and deviations; apply corrective action if ripening becomes non-uniform.

subsections.title: Safety Notes (Ethylene Handling)
subsections.content:
- Prefer safer delivery methods (cartridges/generators) and trained personnel.
- Ensure ventilation between loads and follow facility safety rules for gases and electrical equipment.

subsections.title: Post-Ripening QC and Dispatch
subsections.content:
1) Move fruit to post-ripening storage temperatures:
   - Banana: 13–14°C
   - Mango: 10–13°C
2) Final QC sampling: color stage, firmness (relative), bruising, rot, lot uniformity.
3) Label status: READY-TO-DISPATCH vs. HOLD (extend holding 12–24h if needed).
4) Dispatch: strict FEFO for ripe lots; minimize handling during loading.

sections.title: Monitoring Checklist (Minimum)
sections.content:
- Lot ID, supplier, arrival date/time
- Initial category: UNRIPE / RIPE
- Storage and transit temperatures (where applicable)
- Ripening setpoints (T, RH, ethylene ppm, duration)
- CO₂ readings during ripening (keep < 5000 ppm as a guide)
- Final QC outcomes and dispatch decision
- Deviations and corrective actions
